title: NixOS Package PRs for fzf
description: NixOS Package PRs for fzf on GitHub

items.content_html:
Describe what this PR does / why we need it

This adds the following pickers for fzf-lua:

  • Issues
  • Prs
  • Commits
  • Changed files
  • Project cards
  • Project columns

I picked the ones I use most often. I felt like this was a big enough change to show the pattern I'm going with but small enough to still review appropriately, while also adding some useful functionality.

Does this pull request fix one issue?

NONE (partially #206)

Describe how you did it

Sync calls

Once you look at the code it's obvious this is very directly copied from the Telescope picker implementation, with a few changes. I don't have any experience with Telescope but it seems like it can take data structures that contain functions as entries.

fzf-lua does not (as far as I can tell! I'm still learning :)). In general it takes tables of strings, which are the entries and then the previewing is broken out and based on that string entry.

To supplement fzf-lua's data format I used a pattern common to all the pickers I implemented, shown below

local formatted_issues = {}
local titles = {}

for _, issue in ipairs(issues) do
  local entry = entry_maker.gen_from_issue(issue)

  if entry ~= nil then
    formatted_issues[entry.ordinal] = entry
    table.insert(titles, entry.ordinal)
  end
end

This generates two structures: titles ({ Entry.Ordinal }) which is the table of strings that fzf uses to display the entries and formatted_issues ({ [key: Entry.Ordinal]: Entry } which is referenced for the full data structure when passing data back to Octo.nvim.

Async calls

For two pickers (issues and prs) I found that for active repositories (https://github.com/NixOS/nixpkgs üëÄ) the picker opened after an extremely long wait. To solve this I added a stream_cb to the gh/init.lua file, which gets input from stdout. This allows me to stream the data from the gh calls as it comes in rather than waiting for the data and loading it all at once.

The synchronous pattern above still generally holds, but instead of building out the titles table I called fzf_cb(some_title) to add the entries to fzf. Then finally when the process exits I have fzf_cb() to tell fzf that the loading is done.

Describe how to verify it

  1. Have this branch installed as well as fzf-lua.
  2. Test out following pickers:
    • Issues
    • Prs
    • Commits
    • Changed files
    • Project cards
    • Project columns

Special notes for reviews

  • Question thread is here: ibhagwan/fzf-lua#759
  • TODOs
    • use with-nth to hide ugly lines.
items.title: adds: fzf-lua picker, phase 1

items.content_html:
Things done
  • Built on platform(s)
    • x86_64-linux
    • aarch64-linux
    • x86_64-darwin
    • aarch64-darwin
  • For non-Linux: Is sandbox = true set in nix.conf? (See Nix manual)
  • Tested, as applicable:
    • NixOS test(s) (look inside nixos/tests)
    • and/or package tests
    • or, for functions and "core" functionality, tests in lib/tests or pkgs/test
    • made sure NixOS tests are linked to the relevant packages
  • Tested compilation of all packages that depend on this change using nix-shell -p nixpkgs-review --run "nixpkgs-review rev HEAD". Note: all changes have to be committed, also see nixpkgs-review usage
  • Tested basic functionality of all binary files (usually in ./result/bin/)
  • 23.05 Release Notes (or backporting 22.11 Release notes)
    • (Package updates) Added a release notes entry if the change is major or breaking
    • (Module updates) Added a release notes entry if the change is significant
    • (Module addition) Added a release notes entry if adding a new NixOS module
  • Fits CONTRIBUTING.md.

items.content_html:
Description of changes

Changelog: https://github.com/ocaml/dune/releases/tag/3.8.0

Currently building nixpkgs-review and there appear to be a few regressions that I will fix in due time:

  • ocaml4.14.1-extlib-1.7.7 (appears to be marked as broken)

items.content_html:
Description of changes

Add new package for kns the easy kubernetes namespace switcher. Upstream can be found here: https://github.com/blendle/kns

kns is a shell script that uses fzf to help navigate namespaces within a kubernetes cluster.

I used the existing kubectl-node-shell to base my work on, as they are both fancy bash scripts.

Things done
  • Built on platform(s)
    • x86_64-linux
    • aarch64-linux
    • x86_64-darwin
    • aarch64-darwin
  • For non-Linux: Is sandbox = true set in nix.conf? (See Nix manual)

    • NixOS test(s) (look inside nixos/tests)
    • and/or package tests
    • or, for functions and "core" functionality, tests in lib/tests or pkgs/test
    • made sure NixOS tests are linked to the relevant packages
  • Tested compilation of all packages that depend on this change using nix-shell -p nixpkgs-review --run "nixpkgs-review rev HEAD". Note: all changes have to be committed, also see nixpkgs-review usage
  • Tested basic functionality of all binary files (usually in ./result/bin/)
  • 22.11 Release Notes (or backporting 22.05 Release notes)

Motivation for this change

In many packages, the C compiler is not used, so stdenv could be stdenvNoCC.

Things done

  • Built on platform(s)
    • NixOS
    • macOS
    • other Linux distributions
  • Tested via one or more NixOS test(s) if existing and applicable for the change (look inside nixos/tests)
  • Tested compilation of all pkgs that depend on this change using nix-shell -p nixpkgs-review --run "nixpkgs-review wip"
  • Tested execution of all binary files (usually in ./result/bin/)
  • Determined the impact on package closure size (by running nix path-info -S before and after)
  • Ensured that relevant documentation is up to date
  • Fits CONTRIBUTING.md.
items.title: treewide: use stdenvNoCC when not building

items.content_html:
Description of changes

Plugins for the micro editor.
I was planning on adding a micro.withPlugins, but the only way to add the plugins is either to recompile micro with the plugins present, or to wrap it with a custom $XDG_CONFIG_HOME, which will shadow any other settings, keybindings and plugins present in the user home directory. These plugins will be made use of in nix-community/home-manager#3224
